main_definition: Arbitration is a method of resolving disputes outside of court where an impartial third party, called an arbitrator, makes a decision that is usually binding.

meanings_and_examples.example: The two companies agreed to use arbitration instead of litigation to resolve their contractual disagreements.

meanings_and_examples.definition: An act of making a decision or judgment in favor of one side
meanings_and_examples.example: After carefully listening to both parties, the arbitrator made an arbitral award in favor of the plaintiff.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A specific clause in a contract that requires the disputing parties to resolve their conflict through arbitration
meanings_and_examples.example: The employment agreement included an arbitration clause, stating any work-related disagreements would be settled through this process.

meanings_and_examples.definition: The person or entity appointed to settle a dispute in the context of arbitration
meanings_and_examples.example: The chosen arbitrator was well respected and had decades of experience in resolving commercial disputes.
